title: 111_hr611
content: The Act may be cited as the "Marginal Well Production Preservation and Enhancement Act" and includes tax treatment for prolonged marginal production. Increase in Percentage Depletion for Oil and Natural Gas Produced From Marginal Properties, amending section 613A(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow for 27.5 percent depletion for domestic crude oil and natural gas from marginal properties. The text chunk discusses the coordination of depletion allowances for domestic oil and natural gas production, specifying that no allowance for depletion is allowed for marginal production and such production is not considered in determining depletable quantities. The term 'marginal production' refers to domestic crude oil or natural gas produced from specific properties, such as stripper well properties or those primarily producing heavy oil. The term 'stripper well property' refers to properties with daily production of domestic crude oil and natural gas averaging 15 barrel equivalents or less per well. 'Heavy oil' is defined as domestic crude oil with a weighted average gravity of 20 degrees API or less. The amendment exempts certain depletion allowances from taxable income limits under section 613 of the Internal Revenue Code. It also adjusts definitions related to depletable oil quantity and removes specific references in the code. The amendments made by this subsection apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. Section 613A(c)(6)(H)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend the suspension of taxable income limit from 2010 to 2011. SEC. 3 amends the Clean Air Act by changing a reference from "this section" to "this Act." SEC. 4 pertains to the National Response System. Section 311(j) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include produced water from an oil production facility in the definition of a wastewater treatment facility. The President is required to establish regulations for the removal of discharged oil and hazardous substances in accordance with maritime safety and navigation laws. The President is required to establish regulations for the removal of discharged oil and hazardous substances, including criteria for contingency plans, prevention methods, and inspection of vessels. The Administrator will establish procedures, methods, and equipment requirements for small facilities to prevent discharges and contain them, considering cost-effectiveness. The Administrator will develop regulations for small offshore facilities based on storage volume and capacity, applying to facilities with a total oil storage capacity of at least 1,320 gallons but less than 50,000 gallons. Requirements will be established, eliminating certain engineer certifications and other non-cost-effective measures. The Administrator will develop regulations for small offshore facilities based on storage volume and capacity, applying to facilities with a total oil storage capacity of at least 1,320 gallons but less than 50,000 gallons, to meet cost-effectiveness standards. SEC. 5. RECOVERY PERIOD FOR DEPRECIATION OF PROPERTY USED FOR QUALIFIED TERTIARY INJECTANTS. The amendment defines qualified tertiary injectant property as property used for injecting tertiary injectants in a recovery method. The amendment defines qualified tertiary injectant property as property used for injecting tertiary injectants in a recovery method, including pipelines with a class life of more than 4 years. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment date of this Act, in taxable years ending after such date.
